Dr. Bretherton to leave JHU at end of academic year
By ALAN HIRSCH
After four years as a full
Professor, Dr. Frances
Bretherton, Earth and Planetary
Sciences and Mechanics and
Materials Sciences, will leave
Hopkins at the end of this
academic year.
Bretherton, whose fields of
study include meteorology,
oceanography, and fluid
mechanics, has accepted the
position of President of the
University Center for
Atmospheric Research (UCAR)
in Boulder, Colorado.
According to Bretherton, he is
not leaving Hopkins because he is
dissatisfied. "A major job had to
be filled. I was one of the
candidates and I was selected,"
stated Bretherton. "I've enjoyed
my years here at Hopkins very
much," he added.

Bretherton, already working
part-time for UCAR, will
continue to teach the two
courses he began at the start of
the semester. However, he
asserted that he can no longer
participate in a course in which
he is responsible for one-third of
the instruction.
As president of UCAR,
Bretherton explained that he will
be in charge of a program of
research aimed at gaining a better
understanding of various
considerations of the
atmosphere.
"UCAR is a consortium of 39
Universities throughout the
country," stated Bretherton.
"There are 100 Ph.D.'s involved
in research with UCAR. My
position will be largely an
administrative one and I will be
responsible for the distribution

of the project's $20 million, all
federally funded, to the various
projects," Bretherton said.
"I'm extremely interested in
research and I hope to possibly
get some research of my own
done at the center," continued
Bretherton.
Since coming to Hopkins in
1969, Bretherton has conducted
what he believes to be productive
research in several areas of
science. His research has included
studies in fluid dynamics, waves
in the atmosphere and mid-ocean
dynamics.
Research at UCAR focuses on
the numerical modelling of
motion in the atmosphere,.
Bretherton said. This process,
which involves extensive use of
computers is used in short and
long-range weather prediction.

were important topics discussed
at this year's first meeting of the

held last Wednesday, the first of
the semi-monthly meetings.
Comprised of six faculty
members, three grad students,
yet to be appointed, two

College, one representative of the

nominated by the Student

itself with non-academic matters

of

changes in Hopkins security cited
the current installation of new

walkways. Also, the campus

members.
"Three new officers under 30

"The impression I have is that

become a part, facilitating
identification and return of
stolen bikes.

Union, Fitzpatrick discussed the
several week delay in glass for the

wrap the building in plastic for

improvements in the Levering

service is "operating at a

indicate the emergence of a sorely-needed sensitivity, on the

instituted.

program at Hopkins. Correspondingly, a period of adjustment is
not only permissible but in some case crucial, to the ultimate
fulfillment of the student's goal of medical school acceptance.

making 'damned if you do, damned if you don't' decisions

'freshman grades does not at all imply that the student will not
be considered for admission without them, especially when
subsequent academic records are in order, and when the
withholding of initial grades is the result of an official
University policy whose reasoning is taken seriously by those
charged with its enforcement.

By ROBERT ROSENWASSER
The Johns Hopkins University
soccer team faced Gettysburg of
the Middle Atlantic conference
university division yesterday
afternoon at home. The Hopkins
team has not been beaten in its
last 3 outings and after the dust
had cleared from this non-league
contest, the Blue Jays edged
Gettysburg 1-0.
The close final score is an
excellent indication of how
qvenly played the game was.
From the opening kick-off, a fast
pace was established as both
Gettysburg and Hopkins moved
the ball quickly on offense. Each
team pressed the other's defense
as they exchanged scoring
opportunities throughout the
entire first half.
The lone score in the game
came early at 8:31 as Hopkins
was driving on offense, right wing
Frank Curnoles crossed a high
pass from the right side outside
the goal to lineman John
Hartman, who was perfectly
positioned in front of the goal.
Hartman headed the ball into the
goal. It was a perfectly executed
play and it proved to be the only
goal Hopkins needed to win.
Hopkins made the goal stand
up as the offensive unit
controlled the action in the game

through accurate passing and
driving shots. Gettysburg also
mounted its own scoring threats,_
but the Blue Jay defense did not
allow the Gettysburg linemen to
penetrate near the goal. This
forced Gettysburg to shoot long
hard outside shots, while
Hopkins goalie Keith Naunheim
scooped them up as saves.
For Hopkins, exactly the
opposite was true. Hopkins' ball
control allowed them to drive
deep into Gettysburg territory
where Blue Jay linemen were
able to get off close-range shots.
The Hopkins offense was led by
Phil Heiter and John Hartman,
who took the majority of the
shots.
The game was tense as both
Coach Oliver, the Hopkins
mentor, and the Gettysburg
coach paced the side-lines
nervously, shouting instructions
to their players.
When the horn sounded ending
the first half at score 1-0, both
teams,were ready to take a
breather as they anticipated a
tough second half. The statistics
showed how close the game was.
Hopkins took 7 shots on goal and
Gettysburg had 9. Goalie Keith
Naunheim grabbed 7 saves on the
dazzling Hopkins defense that
thwarted all Gettysburg scoring

threats.
The second half was a
duplicate of the first, as once
again both Hopkins and
Gettysburg continued to switch
offensive attacks.
But it appeared as though
Hopkins slowed down its
offensive game and played much
more cautiously. This enabled
Gettysburg to just put more
pressure on the Hopkins defense
as they drove for the goal.
This was strikingly apparent in
one Gettysburg threat. Their
offense had driven deep into
Hopkins territory and a
Gettysburg lineman had banged a
line drive shot from close range.
But goalie Naunheim turned in
the defensive sparkler of the day
as he ranged to his right to grab
the goalward shot.
At the very end of the game,
Hopkins turned on the offense
and kept excellent control of the
ball to protect that precious one
goal lead. Gettysburg could not
mount another drive as Hopkins
dominated. The game ended at
1-0.
Coach Oliver was pleased with
his team's ability to move the
ball offensively. The Blue Jays
will ready themselves for
tomorrow's game at Franklin and
Marshall.

program at Hopkins. Correspondingly, a period of adjustment is
not only permissible but in some case crucial, to the ultimate

making 'damned if you do, damned if you don't' decisions

'freshman grades does not at all imply that the student will not
be considered for admission without them, especially when
subsequent academic records are in order, and when the
withholding of initial grades is the result of an official
University policy whose reasoning is taken seriously by those
charged with its enforcement.

By ROBERT ROSENWASSER
The Johns Hopkins University
soccer team faced Gettysburg of
the Middle Atlantic conference
university division yesterday
afternoon at home. The Hopkins
team has not been beaten in its
last 3 outings and after the dust
had cleared from this non-league
contest, the Blue Jays edged
Gettysburg 1-0.
The close final score is an
excellent indication of how
qvenly played the game was.
From the opening kick-off, a fast
pace was established as both
Gettysburg and Hopkins moved
the ball quickly on offense. Each
team pressed the other's defense
as they exchanged scoring
opportunities throughout the
entire first half.
The lone score in the game
came early at 8:31 as Hopkins
was driving on offense, right wing
Frank Curnoles crossed a high
pass from the right side outside
the goal to lineman John
Hartman, who was perfectly
positioned in front of the goal.
Hartman headed the ball into the
goal. It was a perfectly executed
play and it proved to be the only
goal Hopkins needed to win.
Hopkins made the goal stand
up as the offensive unit
controlled the action in the game

through accurate passing and
driving shots. Gettysburg also
mounted its own scoring threats,_
but the Blue Jay defense did not
allow the Gettysburg linemen to
penetrate near the goal. This
forced Gettysburg to shoot long
hard outside shots, while
Hopkins goalie Keith Naunheim
scooped them up as saves.
For Hopkins, exactly the
opposite was true. Hopkins' ball
control allowed them to drive
deep into Gettysburg territory
where Blue Jay linemen were
able to get off close-range shots.
The Hopkins offense was led by
Phil Heiter and John Hartman,
who took the majority of the
shots.
The game was tense as both
Coach Oliver, the Hopkins
mentor, and the Gettysburg
coach paced the side-lines
nervously, shouting instructions
to their players.
When the horn sounded ending
the first half at score 1-0, both
teams,were ready to take a
breather as they anticipated a
tough second half. The statistics
showed how close the game was.
Hopkins took 7 shots on goal and
Gettysburg had 9. Goalie Keith
Naunheim grabbed 7 saves on the
dazzling Hopkins defense that
thwarted all Gettysburg scoring

threats.
The second half was a
duplicate of the first, as once
again both Hopkins and
Gettysburg continued to switch
offensive attacks.
But it appeared as though
Hopkins slowed down its
offensive game and played much
more cautiously. This enabled
Gettysburg to just put more
pressure on the Hopkins defense
as they drove for the goal.
This was strikingly apparent in
one Gettysburg threat. Their
offense had driven deep into
Hopkins territory and a
Gettysburg lineman had banged a
line drive shot from close range.
But goalie Naunheim turned in
the defensive sparkler of the day
as he ranged to his right to grab
the goalward shot.
At the very end of the game,
Hopkins turned on the offense
and kept excellent control of the
ball to protect that precious one
goal lead. Gettysburg could not
mount another drive as Hopkins
dominated. The game ended at
1-0.
Coach Oliver was pleased with
his team's ability to move the
ball offensively. The Blue Jays
will ready themselves for
tomorrow's game at Franklin and
Marshall.
